p: The link between epidemiological modeling and policy is long-standing. Bernoulliâ€™s work provides perhaps the earliest case study [ 1]; recent high-profile examples include the use of models to guide responses to foot and mouth disease in the UK [ 111], smallpox [ 112], and influenza [ 113]. The key criterion of the effective deployment of models for policy is that they are embedded in testable hypotheses, embodying the best possible science. Continuing progress in this area thus calls for better understanding of the basic principles.
